This rain analogy as presented in the original tweet is way too caricatured for any meaningful debate. We're both essentially saying the same thing. But to clarify:

Look, I think the problem here is that this whole rain thing is a terrible analogy. But fine. If someone says it's not raining(üôÑ) when it clearly is, and they happen to be crucially relevant to the matter, the reporter is duty-bound to report their views, because public interest

Nobody's saying don't expose the lies. My point is that the "liar" - depending on their relevance to the story - cannot and should not be left out. "Deplatforming", however, is a separate discussion. This isn't it.
I'm not sure that's unique to SL (and I'm not saying that's what you said). There is some discussion in the US, for example, about how the anti-Trump media basically ran his campaign for him in 2016.

Again, this is standard, journalism-101 stuff. I'll grant that you that not all reporters always spend enough time verifying facts due to a number of reasons (tight deadlines on dailies, for one). But a relevant party should never be ignored. At least that's what we were taught.
